data.question: What is the publication year of the article discussing the periodic tiling of pentagons?
Who is the corresponding author for the paper on the first example of a two-dimensional net?
What is the DOI of the article?
How many types of convex pentagons can tile the plane according to the article?
What is the chemical formula of the first example of a modular (5)-network mentioned in the article?
What are the two crucial design elements mentioned for directing the formation of the (5)-net?
data.answer: The nature of the acid functionality, R, in the Cu2(μ-O2CR)4 linker, and the ratio, X, between HMTA and linker.

data.question: What is the expected outcome when HMTA coordinates to 2 Cu2(μ-O2CR)4 linkers?
What structure results from the coordination of four linkers to HMTA?
Is the (5)-network planar according to the article?
data.answer: No, the network cannot be planar.

data.question: Can regular pentagons tile the plane?
Is HMTA known to adopt only one- and two-fold coordination?
Are the sheets of the (5)-network curved?
Does the article report the synthesis of a three-dimensional network?
Is the dinuclear copper carboxylate spacer described as trigonal-pyramidal?
According to the article, are there 14 different types of convex pentagons that cannot tile the plane?
Is the modular nature of the structures limited to coordination of dimetal carboxylates to HMTA?
What is the role of the organic ligand in the majority of modular structures according to the article?
data.answer: To serve as a spacer that links nodes defined by metal geometry.

data.question: What does the coordination of HMTA to three spacers yield?
data.answer: Both 2D three-connected topologies and also 3D topologies depending on the nature of R.

data.question: Are Cu2(μ-O2CR)4-based structures magnetically inactive?
Does the article suggest that the generation of nanoscale cyclopentanoid rings from tetrahedral nodes is irrelevant?
